variant.question: What are the possible consequences of climbing to high level using the autopilot "Vertical Speed" (Vs) mode?

options.text: Decreasing airspeed and the aeroplane may stall.
Increasing airspeed and the aeroplane may stall.
Use of Vs mode is not permitted in the climb.
Increased risk of super stall.

variant.question: If an aircraft is flying at a speed above V~A~:

options.text: a full elevator deflection could cause a structural damage.
the aircraft cannot stall.
the airframe may collapse in a turn.
a high speed warning will be activated.

variant.question: During an emergency descent, the pilot of an aeroplane inadvertently exceeds V~NE~ . In these conditions, what type of hazard should the pilot be aware of?

options.text: Structural damage.
Structural damage if unexpected turbulence is encountered.
Mach tuck.
Uncontrollable yaw moment towards the failed engine in case of an engine failure.

variant.question:
What should a pilot do when exceeding V~MO~/M~MO~?
1. Reduce power to idle 
 2. Use the pitch trim 
 3. Give a nose-up inputThe combination regrouping all correct statements is
For an aeroplane certified under CS-23, VNE is the maximum speed...

options.text: at which the aeroplane may be flown.
which must not be exceeded in a dive.
at which the aeroplane may be flown in cruise.
an aeroplane can be flown at with flaps extended.

variant.question: Regarding the speeds V~NO~, V~MO~ and V~NE~, which of the following answers is correct?

options.text: For an aeroplane certified under CS-25, V~MO~ is the maximum speed that must not be deliberately exceeded in any regime, unless a higher speed has been authorised for a particular flight.
For an aeroplane certified under CS-23, V~NE~ is the maximum speed to be flown with the flaps extended.
V~NO~ is the maximum normal operating airspeed for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It can only be exceeded in smooth air.
V~MO~ is the maximum operating speed permitted in normal conditions for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It may be exceeded by a maximum of 10% in an emergency descent.

variant.question: Considering the speeds V~NO~  , V~NE~  , and V~MO~  , which of the following is correct?

options.text: V~MO~  is the maximum operating speed and may only be exceeded when authorised for a specified flight.
V~NE~     is the "never exceed" maximum speed. Its value varies with altitude.
V~NO~  is the maximum operating speed as specified in CS25.
V~MO~  is the maximum operating speed. It can be exceeded by 10% in an emergency descent.

variant.question: What can happen to the aeroplane structure flying at a speed just exceeding VA?

options.text: It may suffer permanent deformation if the elevator is fully deflected upwards.
It may break if the elevator is fully deflected upwards.
It may suffer permanent deformation because the flight is performed at too large dynamic pressure.
It will collapse if a turn is made.

variant.question: Regarding the speeds VNO, VMO and VNE, which of the following answers is correct?

options.text: For an aeroplane certified under CS-25, VMO is the maximum speed that must not be deliberately exceeded in any regime, unless a higher speed has been authorised for a particular flight.
For an aeroplane certified under CS-23, VNE is the maximum speed to be flown with the flaps extended.
VNO is the maximum normal operating airspeed for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It can only be exceeded in smooth air
VMO is the maximum operating speed permitted in normal conditions for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It may be exceeded by a maximum of 10 % in an emergency descent.

variant.question: Regarding the speeds VNO, VMO and VNE, which of the following answers is correct?

options.text: For an aeroplane certified under CS-25, VMO is the maximum speed that must not be deliberately exceeded in any regime, unless a higher speed has been authorised for a particular flight.
VMO is the maximum operating speed permitted in normal conditions for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It may be exceeded by a maximum of 10% in an emergency descent.
For an aeroplane certified under CS-23, VNE is the maximum speed to be flown with the flaps extended.
VNO is the maximum normal operating airspeed for an aeroplane certified under CS-25. It can only be exceeded in smooth air.
